title: NSW tradies are tampering with scaffolding and risking their lives
text:
Young tradesmen are putting their lives at risk by ignoring safety regulations and tampering with scaffolding.

SafeWork NSW have spent the last six months targeting dodgy scaffolding across the state after the death of 18-year-old Christopher Cassaniti.

The teenager died when the scaffolding he was standing on collapsed at a Macquarie Park construction site in Sydney's north west in April.

Following the accident, a job site was forced to shut down on Friday after it failed to comply with safety regulations, The Daily Telegraph reported.

SafeWork investigators determined key components and materials had been removed from the 15 metre high tower in Caringbah, in south Sydney, meaning it was at risk of collapsing.

Hofly Construction, the site builder, received 11 infringement notices for the 'incomplete scaffold, missing multiple components'.

SafeWork was alerted to the potential danger by Scaffold Logistics, the team which put the scaffold together.

They were reportedly alarmed by how unsteady the 100-tonne construction had become.

The company's national health and safety manager said it was a 'massive risk to the ­industry that any other trade can just remove scaffold ­components'.

The latest incident comes just weeks after Mr Cassaniti's mother insisted on new laws to prosecute those who fail to enforce proper workplace safety

The latest incident comes just weeks after Mr Cassaniti's mother insisted on new laws to prosecute those who fail to enforce proper workplace safety.

'I can never bring my son back and I have come to terms with that,' Mrs Cassaniti said.

'I want the people who are responsible for my son's death to be penalised but I also want to see no other family go through what we have.'

The mother-of-three, from Castle Hill, said dangerous conditions need to be addressed.

'Laws need to be changed immediately.'

She also urged others to not be afraid to 'speak up' about work place issues so risk prevention methods can be implemented.

The State Cabinet has just pushed through reforms which could see companies and individuals penalised for 'gross negligence'.

The amendment to the NSW Work Health and Safety Act is a step up from the current sanction, 'recklessness', which requires prosecutors to prove parties acted with intent.

Government sources said these laws will improve the chances of prosecution compared to other states.
